text: The Straits Times is a newspaper in Singapore. It was started in 1845. It prints news on a broadsheet. The newspaper belongs to Singapore Press Holdings. On August 9, 1965, Singapore left Malaysia and the paper was more focused on Singapore and they created New Straits Times so Malaysians could still read the news. ==History== The newspaper was started in 1845 by Cathick Moses. His friend, Martyrose Apcar wanted to start a local paper, but realized it was too expensive so Moses did. This reference was copied from the main Wikipedia. It was originally a weekly paper but is now printed daily. Itâ€™s called 'the "Sunday Times" when it makes the news on a Sunday. ===1942=== Japan, called the Japanese Empire back in that time had taken Singapore in WW2 and so to avoid being censored Straits Times changed its name to The Shonan Times.Giese, O., 1994, Shooting the War, Annapolis: United States Naval Institute, ISBN 1557503079, citing Page 240, reference copied from the normal Wikipedia It got its name of The Straits Times back when the British took it back. == References == ==Other websites== straitstimes.com Category:1840s establishments in Asia Category:1845 establishments Category:English-language newspapers published in Asia Category:Organizations based in Singapore Category:Singaporean culture
title: The Straits Times
